Award.AwardTitle: FLATE: Florida's Advanced Technological Education Center of Excellence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Florida Advanced Technological Education (FLATE) Center is a statewide ATE Regional Center for Advanced Technological Education that supports manufacturing and its related technology sectors. This project includes three goals as an extension and expansion of FLATE's efforts to: implement a statewide unified education system for manufacturing so that manufacturing education is a convergent curriculum that optimizes technician preparation; provide an effective outreach platform for high school, community college, industry, and legislature access, providing information about the requirement for and impact of manufacturing education in Florida; and present professional development opportunities for STEM educators to develop, refine, and certify their knowledge within manufacturing and its enabling technologies.

Intellectual Merit: FLATE's focus is on three important areas: (i) Curriculum: The Associate of Science (A.S.) degree in Engineering Technology has integrated the national MSSC-CPT certification and the Manufacturing Skills Standards Council Certified Production Technician credential. This represents the first statewide articulation for a national industry credential. (ii) Professional Development: The Engineering Technology Forum is an exemplary model for collaborative professional development. The Forum meets at different Florida State and Community Colleges with a flexible agenda that meets a variety of needs within the College system. (iii) Outreach: The Made in Florida campaign is FLATE's award-winning dissemination platform that uses as its public information window www.madeinflorida.org . Made in Florida is a comprehensive combination of industry tours, videos, STEM student/teacher summer camps, career pathways, recognition awards, student-focused web site, outreach/dissemination events, FLATE FOCUS (a monthly newsletter), and statewide advertorials that are all partially supported by Florida industry.

Broader Impacts: FLATE makes a significant impact on the broader aspects of technical education in Florida. It has developed a method for filtering course, certificate, and degree program content that the Florida Department of Education has delegated to FLATE to apply to new Engineering Technology- based program submissions. FLATE has demonstrated an effective way for community colleges to work directly with Workforce Florida - supported Banner Centers in order to optimize technical workforce education and training efforts statewide. It has included the Manufacturers Association of Florida in an awareness campaign that is instrumental in elevating manufacturing careers as necessary for Florida's economic well being. It has also created a pathway to the ET A.S. Degree program that allows high school students to earn 15 credit hours toward the A.S. Degree.

POR.DRECONTENT:
FLATE's, the Florida Advanced Technology Education Center for Manufacturing, mission is to be the "go-to" organization for manufacturing and advanced technical education, best practices, and resources supporting the high performance skilled workforce for Florida's advanced manufacturing sectors.

 Intellectual Merit : FLATE's activities advance knowledge as framed in its mission.

Curriculum Reform/Development:  Grant activities capitalize on the FLATE built statewide-manufacturing education system with a convergent curriculum that optimizes technician preparation in manufacturing and its enabling technologies.  This nationally recognized model includes: a single statewide engineering technology (ET) associate in science (AS) degree program; completely articulated program structured on a set of core technical courses; alignment with stackable industry credentials endorsed by the National Association of Manufacturers (NAM) and offered by the Manufacturing Skill Standards Council (MSSC); and, for current Certified Production Technician (CPT) credential holders, degree completion with 45 credits rather than 60. 

The ET AS degree program was implemented in 2007, at three colleges.  Today, 24 of the 28 Florida community and State Colleges offer the ET AS Degree; Florida Department of Education enrollment data, indicates a favorable trend from 9 in 2007-08 to 2,027 in 2018-19.  This strong enrollment growth also indicates the degree?s popularity with statewide employers and its stable, college orchestrated, student recruitment platforms.

 Broader Impacts: FLATE's intellectual merit contributions are framed the grant's broader impacts. 

Outreach Initiatives: FLATE has effective outreach platforms for Florida's industry, secondary and post-secondary educational facilities. A 2019-2020 activities effort provides these partners access to legislative information related to the requirements impacting manufacturing education.  For broad public awareness, FLATE maintains online dissemination channels that include: fl-ate.org; MadeinFlorida.org; flate.pbworks.com; and a monthly online newsletter, the flate-mif.blogspot.com. Since 2009, these online resources have provided over 234,000 visitors free access to: information, news, educational resources, interactive lessons to recruit students, and guidebooks to serve the manufacturing education community. 

The FLATE designed Made in Florida's (MIF) Industry tours strategy generates positive images of manufacturing; promotes STEM education to a wide student demographic; and increases awareness of STEM careers pathways for all participants. Since national Manufacturing (MFG) Day's inception in 2013, FLATE's MIF tours are its cornerstone for FLATE's statewide outreach MFG Day/Month. Over 47,095 Florida students and educators were impacted by 1,432 MIF outreach events.  Attendance included 1,916 teachers, 1,080 parents and chaperons participants in events in 50 Florida counties. 

Since 2005, FLATE processed surveys from more than 15,553 students who participated in MIF industry tours. Of the surveys received, there was an average of 47% increase in students? consideration of careers in advanced manufacturing after the tour. This impressive increase confirms the positive impact of the MIF Industry Tours on Florida students. 

FLATE annually hosts and promoted summer camps as an additional supportive, sustainable, and effective mechanism to recruit and motivate students interested in STEM education. Since 2005, FLATE has collaborated with schools and sponsors to offer 1,712 high school and middle school students focused camps on robotics, mechatronics, alternative energy, and manufacturing related career pathways. Camps reflect a best practice for educators and institutions to adapt or replicate. One example, the All-Girls Robotics Camps, includes girl camp scholarships; resources for female recruitment; and FLATE's designed, story-boarded, and produced Women in Manufacturing (WIM) video with its teacher resource guide. 

Professional Development: FLATE's Intellectual Merit related activities generated specific Professional Development (PD) that also amplified the grant's Broader Impacts.  Impact activities relate to ET degree long term success and sustainability as it relates specifically to faculty within the ET AS Degree community and the STEM community at large. 

The Engineering Technology (ET) Forum, coordinated by FLATE, is the premiere Florida State College system faculty two-day bi-annual PD event. The FLATE model for curricula topic forum provides a viable means for industry and educators across the state to meet to discuss common interests and issues surrounding the education of tomorrow's advanced manufacturing workforce. The ET Forum includes the formation of an ET Forum State College Faculty Leadership team and along with the forum funding by the host college and vendor attendees, provides ongoing sustainability.  Even with the significant disruption of education due to COVID-19, 80 participants representing 19 colleges actively participated in the spring 2020 virtual Forum. This model has been replicated at various statewide level programs. 

FLATE created and/or promoted PD opportunities are also offered throughout the year.  FLATE's summer technology and MSSC-CPT workshops are the most popular. Since 2004, FLATE has provided more than 54,700 hours of PD to 15,400 educators (K-14) in multi-day workshops, presentations, and online webinars at hundreds of events in Florida and elsewhere. 

FLATE's success has been possible with the support and partnership of government, education, and industry. FLATE strives to meet emerging needs of educators, students and workforce providing value for industry partners as it builds Florida's 21st-century technical workforce.


Last Modified: 06/25/2020
Modified by: Marilyn Barger
